headline: Warner Bros. Says Over 93% of Its Holders Reject Paramount's Bid
summary: Paramount Skydance again extended its tender offer for Warner Bros. Discovery shares and said it would ask investors to vote against a proposed sale to Netflix at a special meeting of Warner Bros. shareholders. Warner Bros. Discovery says more than 93% of its shareholders are rejecting Paramount's offer, according to a statement. Bloomberg's Chris Palmeri discussed the story on "Bloomberg Markets" with Scarlet Fu.

headline: Paramount Extends Deadline on Warner Bros. Offer. It Won’t Be Enough to Woo Investors.
summary: The CBS owner said in a statement that it would extend the deadline for its tender offer but stuck by its $30-a-share bid.

raw.headline: Paramount Extends Deadline on Warner Bros. Offer. It Won’t Be Enough to Woo Investors.
raw.summary: The CBS owner said in a statement that it would extend the deadline for its tender offer but stuck by its $30-a-share bid.

headline: Paramount Extends Warner Bros. Discovery Tender Deadline
summary: Paramount extended the deadline on its tender offer for Warner Bros. Discovery to Feb. 20 and urged shareholders on Thursday to reject the latest offer from rival suitor Netflix.  The extension gives Paramount more time to court Warner shareholders with its $77.9 billion offer for the full company.  Warner said earlier this week that it had struck a new, all-cash deal with Netflix for its studios and HBO Max streaming service, valued at $72 billion.

raw.headline: Paramount Extends Warner Bros. Discovery Tender Deadline
raw.summary: Paramount extended the deadline on its tender offer for Warner Bros. Discovery to Feb. 20 and urged shareholders on Thursday to reject the latest offer from rival suitor Netflix.  The extension gives Paramount more time to court Warner shareholders with its $77.9 billion offer for the full company.  Warner said earlier this week that it had struck a new, all-cash deal with Netflix for its studios and HBO Max streaming service, valued at $72 billion.

headline: Paramount extends its deadline for its Warner Bros. Discovery tender offer, again
summary: Skydance-owned Paramount is again extending the tender offer window in its $77.9 billion hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, while doubling down on a coming proxy fight.  Warner stockholders now have until Feb. 20 to sell their shares to Paramount for $30 apiece in cash — a price that remains unchanged, giving the offer a total enterprise value of over $108 billion including debt.  It marks the second extension the company has made since challenging Warner’s merger agreement with Netflix last month.

raw.headline: Paramount extends its deadline for its Warner Bros. Discovery tender offer, again

Warner stockholders now have until Feb. 20 to sell their shares to Paramount for $30 apiece in cash — a price that remains unchanged, giving the offer a total enterprise value of over $108 billion including debt.  It marks the second extension the company has made since challenging Warner’s merger agreement with Netflix last month.

headline: Paramount extends tender offer deadline to woo Warner shareholders as proxy fight heats up
summary: Paramount has asked Warner shareholders to sell their shares by Feb. 20. The company also vowed to challenge the Netflix deal during a meeting of Warner shareholders.

headline: Paramount extends deadline on hostile Warner Bros bid to February 20
summary: Jan 22 () - Paramount Skydance on Thursday extended the deadline on its hostile tender offer for Warner Bros Discovery to February 20, giving it more time to persuade investors that its bid ​for the Hollywood studio trumps a rival deal with Netflix. With DC Comics, iconic franchises from "Friends" to "Batman" ‌and the HBO Max streaming service at stake, a successful deal would change the power dynamics of Hollywood and could help power growth ‌at its suitor for years to come.

headline: Why Europe will be so important to a WBD deal
summary: The future of the Warner Bros. Discovery cable networks, including CNN, TBS, TNT, Discovery and HGTV, and its U.S. sports rights may come down to European regulators.
